That's why he felt a wave of frustration wash over him, a sense of betrayal that lingered long after he left the precinct behind. Triggering Event: At 74, he sat alone in his cluttered study, eyes scanning the yellowed photograph of his late colleague. Their groundbreaking research, once his pride, now echoed with unspoken regret. He'd walked away from a Nobel Prize nomination to protect his partner's career, but she'd left him years later. The silence was deafening; only the ticking clock bore witness to his quiet despair.
Generated Assessment: He couldn't bring himself to look at the photo anymore. It was too painful, reminding him that his decision had cost him everything. His life had been reduced to one thing: regret. Every day felt like a countdown until death would finally put him out of his misery. He wondered if anyone else knew how much it hurt to miss out on something so precious. # Edit: I understand what this is now. Thank you for all the comments and feedback! If you are struggling with this issue, please reach out to someone who can help you, whether it's a therapist or support group. There is no shame in needing help. Please don’t struggle in isolation. If you’re looking for resources, here are some options: * National Suicide Prevention Lifeline (US): 1-800-273-TALK (8255) * Crisis Text Line (US): Text HOME to 741741 * Befrienders Worldwide: <https://www.befrienders.org/> (for those outside the US) * Samaritans (UK): 116 123 * Lifeline Australia: 13 11 14 * Beyond Blue Australia: <https://www.beyondblue.org.au/> * Canadian Association for Suicide Prevention: <https://caosp.ca/> Please take care and remember that you are not alone. You are loved, valued
